question:
A.01  [1.0 point]
Using the applicable portion from the chart of the nuclides, what will Mn-56 decay into?

a. Mn-55
b. Fe-56
c. Fe-58
d. Co-60

answers.answer: a. Mn-55
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Mn-56 is beta decay, which is the conversion of a neutron into a proton and electron. Reference: Baum, E., Knox, H., and Miller, T., 2002. Nuclides and Isotopes 16th Ed. pg. 28.

answers.answer: b. Fe-56
answers.feedback: Correct. Mn-56 is beta decay, which is the conversion of a neutron into a proton and electron. Reference: Baum, E., Knox, H., and Miller, T., 2002. Nuclides and Isotopes 16th Ed. pg. 28.

answers.answer: c. Fe-58
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Mn-56 is beta decay, which is the conversion of a neutron into a proton and electron. Reference: Baum, E., Knox, H., and Miller, T., 2002. Nuclides and Isotopes 16th Ed. pg. 28.

answers.answer: d. Co-60
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Mn-56 is beta decay, which is the conversion of a neutron into a proton and electron. Reference: Baum, E., Knox, H., and Miller, T., 2002. Nuclides and Isotopes 16th Ed. pg. 28.

question:
A.02  [1.0 point]
What effect does moderator temperature have on neutron population?

a. As the density of the moderator decreases, less moderation occurs and more neutrons leaks from the core.
b. As the density of the moderator increases, less moderation occurs and more neutrons leaks from the core.
c. As the density of the moderator decreases, more moderation occurs and less neutrons leak from the core.
d. As the density of the moderator increases, less moderation occurs and less neutrons leak from the core.

answers.answer: a. As the density of the moderator decreases, less moderation occurs and more neutrons leaks from the core.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 6.5, pg. 6-14

answers.answer: b. As the density of the moderator increases, less moderation occurs and more neutrons leaks from the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 6.5, pg. 6-14

answers.answer: c. As the density of the moderator decreases, more moderation occurs and less neutrons leak from the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 6.5, pg. 6-14

answers.answer: d. As the density of the moderator increases, less moderation occurs and less neutrons leak from the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 6.5, pg. 6-14

question:
A.03  [1.0 point]
The product of number density and microscopic cross section of an element is defined as:

a. Macroscopic Cross Section.
b. Thermal Cross Section.
c. Mean Free Path.
d. Decay Constant.

answers.answer: a. Macroscopic Cross Section.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 2.5.2, pg. 2-43

answers.answer: b. Thermal Cross Section.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.5.2, pg. 2-43

answers.answer: c. Mean Free Path.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.5.2, pg. 2-43

answers.answer: d. Decay Constant.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.5.2, pg. 2-43

question:
A.04  [1.0 point]
The following graph for U-235 depicts…

a. Axial flux distribution in the core.
b. Fission product yield distribution.
c. Radial flux distribution in the core.
d. Neutron energy distribution in the moderator.

answers.answer: a. Axial flux distribution in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

answers.answer: b. Fission product yield distribution.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

answers.answer: c. Radial flux distribution in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

answers.answer: d. Neutron energy distribution in the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

question:
A.05  [1.0 point]
A 1/M curve is being generated as fuel is loaded into the core. After some fuel elements have been loaded, the count rate existing at that time is taken to be the new initial count rate.  Additional elements are then loaded, and the inverse count rate ratio continues to decrease. As a result of changing the initial count rate:

a. Predicted criticality will occur with the same number of elements loaded as if the initial count rate had not been changed.
b. Predicted criticality will occur earlier (i.e., with fewer elements loaded).
c. Predicted criticality will occur later (i.e., with more elements loaded).
d. Criticality will be completely unpredictable.

answers.answer: a. Predicted criticality will occur with the same number of elements loaded as if the initial count rate had not been changed.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burns, Section 5.5, pg. 5-18

answers.answer: b. Predicted criticality will occur earlier (i.e., with fewer elements loaded).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burns, Section 5.5, pg. 5-18

answers.answer: c. Predicted criticality will occur later (i.e., with more elements loaded).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burns, Section 5.5, pg. 5-18

answers.answer: d. Criticality will be completely unpredictable.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burns, Section 5.5, pg. 5-18

question:
A.06  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following is the definition for Differential Control Rod Worth? The reactivity:

a. Due to control rod position (ΔK/K).
b. Change per unit of rod motion (ΔK/K/in).
c. Due to the difference in rod speed (ΔK/K/in/min).
d. Still available for shutdown after control rod withdrawal.

answers.answer: a. Due to control rod position (ΔK/K).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The reactivity change per unit movement of a rod is normally expressed as in/r/inch, ΔK/K per inch, or pcm/inch. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 52

answers.answer: b. Change per unit of rod motion (ΔK/K/in).
answers.feedback: Correct. The reactivity change per unit movement of a rod is normally expressed as in/r/inch, ΔK/K per inch, or pcm/inch. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 52

answers.answer: c. Due to the difference in rod speed (ΔK/K/in/min).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The reactivity change per unit movement of a rod is normally expressed as in/r/inch, ΔK/K per inch, or pcm/inch. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 52

answers.answer: d. Still available for shutdown after control rod withdrawal.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The reactivity change per unit movement of a rod is normally expressed as in/r/inch, ΔK/K per inch, or pcm/inch. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 52

question:
A.07  [1.0 point]
The longest-lived DNP group has a half-life of _______ seconds.

a. 0.026
b. 0.1
c. 55
d. 80

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.2.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.2.2
Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 3.2.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.2.2

question:
A.08  [1.0 point]
The process in which a neutron strikes a nucleus leaving the nucleus in an excited state is referred to as:

a. Elastic scattering
b. Inelastic scattering
c. Radiative capture
d. Neutron annihilation

answers.answer: a. Elastic scattering
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.4, pg. 2-28

answers.answer: b. Inelastic scattering
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 2.4, pg. 2-28

answers.answer: c. Radiative capture
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.4, pg. 2-28

answers.answer: d. Neutron annihilation
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.4, pg. 2-28

question:
A.09  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following best describes the source of Nitrogen-16 produced in the reactor primary coolant system?

a. Neutron decay of deuterium.
b. Neutron activation of a nitrogen atom.
c. Neutron scattering of the nucleus of a boron atom.
d. Neutron (n,p) particle ejection by the nucleus of an oxygen atom.

answers.answer: a. Neutron decay of deuterium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Table 10.7, pg. 599

answers.answer: b. Neutron activation of a nitrogen atom.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Table 10.7, pg. 599

answers.answer: c. Neutron scattering of the nucleus of a boron atom.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Table 10.7, pg. 599

answers.answer: d. Neutron (n,p) particle ejection by the nucleus of an oxygen atom.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Table 10.7, pg. 599

question:
A.10  [1.0 point]
The probability that a thermal neutron will be absorbed in the fuel is referred to as:

a. Reproduction probability
b. Thermal utilization probability
c. Thermal non-leakage probability
d. Resonance escape probability

answers.answer: a. Reproduction probability
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3, pg. 3-16

answers.answer: b. Thermal utilization probability
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3, pg. 3-16

answers.answer: c. Thermal non-leakage probability
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3, pg. 3-16

answers.answer: d. Resonance escape probability
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3, pg. 3-16

question:
A.11  [1.0 point]
During Reg Rod calibration, doubling time was recorded to be 78 seconds. What was reactor period?

a. 39 seconds
b. 54 seconds
c. 113 seconds
d. 156 seconds

answers.answer: a. 39 seconds
answers.feedback: Incorrect. T = Doubling Time/ln(2) = 78 seconds/0.693 = 112.55 = 113 seconds

answers.answer: b. 54 seconds
answers.feedback: Incorrect. T = Doubling Time/ln(2) = 78 seconds/0.693 = 112.55 = 113 seconds

answers.answer: c. 113 seconds
answers.feedback: Correct. T = Doubling Time/ln(2) = 78 seconds/0.693 = 112.55 = 113 seconds

answers.answer: d. 156 seconds
answers.feedback: Incorrect. T = Doubling Time/ln(2) = 78 seconds/0.693 = 112.55 = 113 seconds

question:
A.12  [1.0 point]
In a comparison between a delayed neutron and a prompt neutron born from the same fission event, the delayed neutron is more likely to:

a. Leak out of the core.
b. Be absorbed in the moderator.
c. Cause fission of a u-238 nucleus.
d. Cause fission of a u-235 nucleus.

answers.answer: a. Leak out of the core.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2

answers.answer: b. Be absorbed in the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2

answers.answer: c. Cause fission of a u-238 nucleus.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2

answers.answer: d. Cause fission of a u-235 nucleus.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2

question:
A.13  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following describes the factors that have the greatest effect on the fast fission factor?

a. Arrangement and concentrations of the fuel and the moderator.
b. Arrangement and temperatures of the fuel and the moderator.
c. Enrichment of the fuel and temperature of the moderator.
d. Enrichment of the fuel and concentration of the moderator.

answers.answer: a. Arrangement and concentrations of the fuel and the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 3

answers.answer: b. Arrangement and temperatures of the fuel and the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 3

answers.answer: c. Enrichment of the fuel and temperature of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 3

answers.answer: d. Enrichment of the fuel and concentration of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-03, pg. 3

question:
A.14  [1.0 point]
A critical reactor is operating at a low power level below POAH (point of added heat).  When the primary pump is turned off decreasing the rate of flow of the coolant through the reactor. What affect will the change in coolant flow rate have on reactivity?

a. Varying the coolant flow at low power levels does not result in measurable reactivity changes.
b. Varying the coolant flow at low power levels will cause the addition of positive reactivity due to reduction in pressure, resulting in a prompt drop.
c. Varying the coolant flow at low power levels will cause the addition of negative reactivity due to the increase of coolant density, resulting in a power level increase.
d. Varying the reactor coolant flow low power levels will cause the addition of negative reactivity due to the increase in coolant temperature, resulting in the reactor becoming subcritical.

answers.answer: a. Varying the coolant flow at low power levels does not result in measurable reactivity changes.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-04, pg. 30

answers.answer: b. Varying the coolant flow at low power levels will cause the addition of positive reactivity due to reduction in pressure, resulting in a prompt drop.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-04, pg. 30

answers.answer: c. Varying the coolant flow at low power levels will cause the addition of negative reactivity due to the increase of coolant density, resulting in a power level increase.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-04, pg. 30

answers.answer: d. Varying the reactor coolant flow low power levels will cause the addition of negative reactivity due to the increase in coolant temperature, resulting in the reactor becoming subcritical.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-04, pg. 30

question:
A.15  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following best describes the relationship between reactor power and neutron flux?

a. Reactor power is two times greater than the fission rate of the fuel.
b. Reactor power increases exponentially as the fission rate increases.
c. The rate of energy produced by the reactor is linearly proportional to the fission rate in the core.
d. Thermal power can be calculated by multiplying the neutron flux by the total volume of the core.

answers.answer: a. Reactor power is two times greater than the fission rate of the fuel.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.8, pg. 2-64

answers.answer: b. Reactor power increases exponentially as the fission rate increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.8, pg. 2-64

answers.answer: c. The rate of energy produced by the reactor is linearly proportional to the fission rate in the core.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 2.8, pg. 2-64

answers.answer: d. Thermal power can be calculated by multiplying the neutron flux by the total volume of the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 2.8, pg. 2-64

question:
A.16  [1.0 point, 0.25 each]
Identify whether each of the following conditions will INCREASE or DECREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor.

a. Burnout of a burnable poison.
b. Insertion of boron graphite to the reactor core.
c. Moving one fuel element from reactor core to fuel storage.
d. Insertion of a fueled ICSA (in-core sample assembly).

answers.answer: (a) DECREASE, (b) INCREASE, (c) INCREASE, (d) DECREASE
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 2, NP-04, pg.28

question:
A.17  [1.0 point]
While a reactor is at 5 W, the reactor operator is withdrawing a control rod to insert a positive reactivity of 0.00156 (ΔK/K). Which ONE of the following will be the stable reactor period as a result of this withdrawal? Given beta-effective = 0.0073 and λeff= 0.1.

a. 17 seconds
b. 27 seconds
c. 37 seconds
d. 47 seconds

answers.answer: a. 17 seconds
answers.feedback:
Incorrect. Reactivity added = 156 pcm = 0.00156 (ΔK/K)
t = β/(ρ-λeffβ) = (0.0073) / (0.00156 - (0.1)(0.0073)) = 37 seconds

answers.answer: b. 27 seconds
answers.feedback:
Incorrect. Reactivity added = 156 pcm = 0.00156 (ΔK/K)
t = β/(ρ-λeffβ) = (0.0073) / (0.00156 - (0.1)(0.0073)) = 37 seconds

answers.answer: c. 37 seconds
answers.feedback:
Correct. Reactivity added = 156 pcm = 0.00156 (ΔK/K)
t = β/(ρ-λeffβ) = (0.0073) / (0.00156 - (0.1)(0.0073)) = 37 seconds

answers.answer: d. 47 seconds
answers.feedback:
Incorrect. Reactivity added = 156 pcm = 0.00156 (ΔK/K)
t = β/(ρ-λeffβ) = (0.0073) / (0.00156 - (0.1)(0.0073)) = 37 seconds

question:
A.18  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following describes a property of a GOOD MODERATOR?

a. It slows down fast neutrons to thermal energy levels via a small number of collisions.
b. It reduces gamma radiation to thermal energy levels via a small number of collisions.
c. It slows down fast neutrons to thermal energy levels via a large number of collisions.
d. It reduces gamma radiation to thermal energy levels via a large number of collisions.

answers.answer: a. It slows down fast neutrons to thermal energy levels via a small number of collisions.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 1, NP-02, pg. 23

answers.answer: b. It reduces gamma radiation to thermal energy levels via a small number of collisions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 1, NP-02, pg. 23

answers.answer: c. It slows down fast neutrons to thermal energy levels via a large number of collisions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 1, NP-02, pg. 23

answers.answer: d. It reduces gamma radiation to thermal energy levels via a large number of collisions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals of Reactor Theory, Volume 1, NP-02, pg. 23

question:
A.19  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following is a number of neutrons in the Uranium-235 nucleus  (₉₂U²³⁵)?

a. 92
b. 143
c. 235
d. The U-235 doesn’t have a constant number of neutrons, it fluctuates between 95 and 140.

answers.feedback:
Incorrect. N = A - Z
235-92 = 143

Correct. N = A - Z
235-92 = 143

Incorrect. N = A - Z
235-92 = 143

answers.answer: d. The U-235 doesn’t have a constant number of neutrons, it fluctuates between 95 and 140.
answers.feedback:
Incorrect. N = A - Z
235-92 = 143

question:
A.20  [1.0 point]
Which ONE of the following correctly describes the SIX-FACTOR FORMULA?

a. K∞ = Keff * the total leakage probability
b. K∞ = Keff * the reproduction factor
c. Keff = K∞ * the total non-leakage probability
d. Keff = (K∞ - (the resonance escape probability * the reproduction factor))

answers.answer: a. K∞ = Keff * the total leakage probability
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3

answers.answer: b. K∞ = Keff * the reproduction factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3

answers.answer: c. Keff = K∞ * the total non-leakage probability
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 3

answers.answer: d. Keff = (K∞ - (the resonance escape probability * the reproduction factor))
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3
